projects.title: Teaserfly
projects.summary: Automation suite for generating AI-driven teaser visuals and video packages across BILD platforms, integrating editorial workflows and design automation.
projects.impact: Reduced teaser production time by 90%, enabling editors to generate cross-platform media packages autonomously.
projects.story:
# The Challenge

The BILD editorial and design teams faced an increasing need for **fast, high-quality teaser creation** across multiple platforms, from Bild.de and Bild Play to YouTube, Instagram, and other social channels. The traditional process relied heavily on designers, taking up to 15 minutes per teaser, often under tight news deadlines.

# The Solution

To address this, we conceptualized and developed **Teaserfly**, a modular and scalable internal tool that automates teaser production using **AI generation, smart text suggestions, and media optimization**. The project was designed to fit seamlessly into existing publishing CMS, streamlining editorial and visual workflows.

### My Role

I played a key role in shaping the **concept, infraestructure, and AI research** behind Teaserfly. I also contributed to the **frontend architecture (React, TypeScript)** and **AI enhancement layer**.

# The Approach

Teaserfly was developed in multiple phases:

- **POC:** Manual MVP via Figma plugin for the Bundesliga vertical teaser.
- **Alpha:** Web prototype integrating text and image AI features.
- **Beta:** Expanded for all templates, auto-suggestions using article text.

![User Flow Diagram](/assets/projects/teaserfly/teaserFlyUserFlow.png)

# AI Features

- **Design Automation:** Smart cropping and layout adjustments using Amazon Rekognition.
- **Headline Optimization:** AI-powered text suggestions for each platform.
- **Add-on Intelligence:** Automatic inclusion of Ad elements, video tags, and logos.
- **Image Recommendations:** Sugestion of images based on the context.
- **Creation Agent – 'Teasy':** An optional assistant that helps editors refine graphics interactively.

# Integration

Teaserfly connects directly with internal publishing tools, ensuring editors can **create, preview, and publish teasers** in one flow:
- Pushes to **CMS** and **DAM System**.
- Supports export for third-party platforms (YouTube, Instagram).

<video controls style="width: 100%; border-radius: 1rem; margin: 2rem 0;">
  <source src="/assets/projects/teaserfly/teaserflyDemo.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

# Results

- **90% reduction** in manual work time (from 15 min to 90 sec per teaser)
- **Standardized design output** across all formats
- **AI-powered scalability**, handling hundreds of assets daily
- **Empowered newsroom teams** to operate independently of design bottlenecks

# Future Vision

Teaserfly continues to evolve with the introduction of **personalization, A/B testing, and dynamic design adaptation** — using real-time performance data and multilingual optimization to push editorial automation even further.

This is a company project developed internally at Axel Springer GmbH, no public demo or code repository can be shared.

projects.title: Quem Fica em Pé
projects.summary: Game show control system for the Brazilian adaptation of 'Who’s Still Standing?', automating real-time graphics, questions, and prize management for live television broadcast.
projects.impact: Delivered a fully integrated real-time game control suite in two weeks, ensuring flawless live operation and boosting the show's premiere audience ratings on Band.
projects.story:
# The Challenge

In 2012, Rede Bandeirantes brought the international format of *'Who’s Still Standing?'* to Brazil, launching the game show **'Quem Fica em Pé'**, hosted by **José Luiz Datena**. The production demanded a complete digital control ecosystem built from scratch in just **two weeks** — responsible for managing every part of the game’s mechanics in real time.

![Studio Demo](/assets/projects/quemficaempe/demo.jpg)

The system needed to integrate seamlessly with **Vizrt broadcast graphics**, synchronize with the presenter’s timing, and guarantee the accurate calculation of prizes — totaling **over R$500,000** in awards across two seasons. According to the show’s Wikipedia page, the premiere significantly **improved Band’s audience ratings** in the São Paulo region.

# The Solution

A fully custom-built, C#-based platform was developed to manage the entire show logic, with three interconnected applications working in real time:

1. **Game Management System** – Proprietary CMS for registering over **3,000 questions**, managing rounds, prizes, and the complete rundown of each episode.
2. **Vizrt Control Connector** – Real-time TCP socket controller for graphics and animations displayed on the studio’s large screen, ensuring frame-perfect sync with Datena’s narration.
3. **Teleprompter System (TP)** – Interface for presenters and contestants displaying dynamic instructions and timed content during live recording.

 ![SystemScreen](/assets/projects/quemficaempe/tela1.png)

# My Role

I designed the system’s architecture, coded every module, and developed **custom connectors for Vizrt integration**. My responsibilities included:

- Building the CMS and control interfaces
- Implementing the scoring and prize logic
- Managing TCP socket communication between systems
- Supporting live studio operations throughout the first season

# The Approach

Development was fast-paced and highly collaborative. I worked closely with the **engineering, art, and direction teams** to align visual and technical workflows. The system’s architecture combined **C#**, **PostgreSQL**, and **TCP-based real-time control**, delivering a stable, low-latency experience during broadcast.

# Team & Production

- **Program Director:** Pablo Mazover  
- **Production Coordination:** Eduardo Gaspar  
- **Art Direction:** Omar Sabbag  
- **Art Coordination:** Pedro Coelho  
- **Engineering Coordination:** Thiago Perrela / Carol Garcia  

# Results

- **Full delivery within two weeks** before the live premiere
- **Zero technical failures** during broadcast
- **Perfect synchronization** between presenter, visuals, and scoring system
- **Boosted Band’s audience ratings** in the premiere week
- Early Brazilian example of **live game automation integrated with broadcast graphics**

<video controls style="width: 100%; border-radius: 1rem; margin: 2rem 0;">
  <source src="/assets/projects/quemficaempe/demo.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

# Legacy

'Quem Fica em Pé' set a benchmark for **interactive broadcast automation** in Brazilian television, inspiring future projects focused on real-time synchronization and audience engagement.

projects.title: Riot Games – CBLOL Telemetry 2016
projects.summary: Real-time telemetry system integrating biometric data from players into live eSports broadcasts for Riot Games' CBLOL 2016, connecting Zephyr sensors to Vizrt graphics via custom-built C# software.
projects.impact: Delivered the first human telemetry integration in Brazilian eSports broadcasts, enriching live storytelling under high operational pressure and compliance constraints.
projects.story:
# The Challenge

During the **CBLOL 2016** broadcasts, **Riot Games Brasil** aimed to redefine the eSports viewing experience by introducing **human telemetry**—tracking players’ heart rate, breathing, and stress levels—to reveal the physical and emotional intensity behind professional gaming.

The initiative took place under **significant pressure from Riot’s production leadership**, as audience numbers were at record highs and expectations for innovation were enormous. Furthermore, strict **compliance and operational safety policies** mandated that no system could interfere with gameplay performance or jeopardize the broadcast, even in case of failure.

The technical environment posed additional challenges: over **2,000 spectators** in the arena, high electromagnetic interference, and numerous wireless devices caused instability in Bluetooth communications.

# The Solution

Working as a **freelance systems engineer**, I developed a two-part telemetry pipeline connecting **Zephyr biometric sensors** worn by the ten players to the **Vizrt** graphics system operated by **wTVision**. The goal was to stream real-time physiological data safely into the broadcast layer without impacting the competition.

Two complementary applications were built in **C#**:

1. **Bluetooth Reader (NUC – Under Stage)**  
   Installed beneath the main stage, this application handled **Bluetooth pairing, decoding, and data normalization** for all ten players’ Zephyr sensors. It managed signal stability and transmitted readings over **TCP Stream**.

2. **Telemetry Controller (Control Room)**  
   Running from the control room, it received data via TCP, processed and formatted it in **JSON**, and sent it via **UDP** to **Vizrt**, where graphics were updated live on screen. It also functioned as a monitoring dashboard, allowing real-time tracking of player vitals.

![System Diagram](/assets/projects/riot-telemetry/diagram.jpg)

# My Role

I was responsible for designing and coding both systems end-to-end:

- Built the **Bluetooth decoding layer** for Zephyr sensors.
- Implemented **TCP/UDP communication middleware** to link stage and control room with minimal latency.
- Developed a **real-time compliance logic** ensuring that signal loss would never impact gameplay or broadcast continuity.
- Supported **live operations** throughout the event, troubleshooting Bluetooth instability under high interference.

<video controls style="width: 100%; border-radius: 1rem; margin: 2rem 0;">
  <source src="/assets/projects/riot-telemetry/demo.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

# The Approach

The project was executed in **three weeks**, involving close coordination between **Riot Games**, **wTVision**, and the local production crew. The architecture prioritized **redundancy, reliability, and isolation**, ensuring that any sensor or network failure would not affect live performance.

Although magnetic noise caused **some instability during the event**, the system remained operational and successfully displayed live biometric data throughout the competition—marking a pioneering moment in Brazilian eSports broadcasting.

# Results

- **First-ever human telemetry integration** in a Brazilian eSports broadcast.
- **Operational compliance** achieved — no interference with gameplay or broadcast continuity.
- **Functional real-time data visualization** via Vizrt graphics.
- **Performance rated as satisfactory** despite expected signal interference.
- Praised by **Riot Games Brasil** and **wTVision** as an innovative step forward for live eSports production.

![Control Room Screen](/assets/projects/riot-telemetry/screen1.png)
